Lesson 1.1- Exploring the Social Sciences Homework

Course: HHS4U – Families in Canada
Type of Assessment: Conversation Activity (Not a Product-Based Assessment)
Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning
Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Rationale for Conversation-Based Assessment

Conversations allow students to demonstrate their understanding through dialogue, refining their ability to articulate social science concepts, analyze perspectives, and engage in critical discussion. This method assesses their ability to think on the spot, synthesize information, and engage in thoughtful academic discourse, rather than simply producing written work.

Ontario Curriculum Expectations Assessed:

  • A1.1 Explore a variety of topics related to families in Canada to identify topics for research and inquiry.

  • A1.2 Identify key concepts related to selected topics (e.g., through discussion, brainstorming, use of visual organizers).

  • A1.3 Formulate effective questions to guide research and inquiry.

Assignment Instructions

Step 1: Preparing for the Discussion

Before participating in this conversation, reflect on how personal experiences shape our understanding of social issues and how social science research provides a broader, evidence-based approach to these issues.

To prepare:

  • Think of a real-life experience that shaped your views on a social issue (e.g., poverty, gender roles, family dynamics).

  • Consider how a social scientist might approach the same issue differently.

  • Research how qualitative or quantitative research methods are used in social sciences to explore social issues.

Step 2: Participating in Discussion in Brightspace Forum

In this discussion, you will engage with your classmates and teacher by addressing the following points related to a social issue that has shaped your personal views. Your responses should be well thought out, demonstrate critical thinking, and show your ability to connect personal experiences with academic perspectives.

Discussion Points:

  1. Describe a Social Issue:
     Share a social issue that has had a significant impact on your views. Explain how this issue has influenced your perspective.

  2. Compare Perspectives:
     Compare your personal perspective with how a sociologist, anthropologist, or psychologist might analyze the issue. What differences or similarities do you notice in the way these fields approach the topic?

  3. Discuss the Importance of Research:
     Explain why research is crucial in understanding social issues. How does research help form conclusions about a problem?

  4. Explore the Role of Research Questions:
     Discuss how focused research questions help uncover insights that personal experiences might miss. Why are research questions so important for researchers in understanding social issues?

Guidelines for Participation:

  • Your initial post should be 200–300 words, addressing the four points above.

  • Respond thoughtfully to at least two peers. Your responses should be 50–100 words each and engage with the points made by your classmates. Ask questions or offer additional insights to encourage further discussion.

  • Make sure to incorporate sociological concepts and relevant research where appropriate.

  • Critical thinking and academic engagement are key components of this discussion.

Step 3: Reflection on the Conversation (Post-Discussion)

After the conversation, take a few minutes to reflect:

  • What new insights did you gain from discussing the issue?

  • Did you change or refine your perspective based on the discussion?

  • How did this experience help you understand the difference between personal opinions and academic research?

You may be asked to provide a written or verbal reflection summarizing these points.

Assessment Rubric (KTCA – Conversation-Based Assessment)

Criteria

Level 1 (50-59%)

Level 2 (60-69%)

Level 3 (70-79%)

Level 4 (80-100%)

Knowledge and Understanding

Limited understanding of how personal experiences relate to social science research.

Basic understanding with minimal connections to social science perspectives.

Clear understanding with well-supported analysis; makes relevant comparisons.

Sophisticated understanding, effectively integrates personal insights with research perspectives.

Thinking and Inquiry

Weak or unclear differentiation between personal perspectives and social science research methods.

Some analysis of differences between personal views and research perspectives, but lacks depth.

Thoughtful analysis with relevant examples; understands distinctions well.

Insightful and well-reasoned analysis; deeply explores differences between experiences and research.

Communication

Ideas are unclear and poorly articulated; lacks cohesion in responses.

Basic communication of ideas; some responses lack organization or depth.

Clear communication of ideas, with minor issues in coherence.

Exceptionally clear, well-organized, and engaging discussion.

Application

No use of focused research questions; cannot apply academic perspectives to social issues.

Limited use of research questions; basic application to social issues.

Effective use of focused research questions with good application.

Skillful use of highly focused research questions; excellent application to explore issues.

Lesson 1.3 - Learning to Research Homework

Course: HHS4U – Families in Canada

Type of Assessment: Conversation

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning

Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Rationale for Assessment:
 This activity promotes the development of critical research and evaluation skills by engaging students in a systematic process of investigating and analyzing sources related to human behavior or societal issues. By focusing on primary and secondary sources, students enhance their ability to assess the quality and relevance of information. The discussion forum component encourages peer engagement, allowing students to share insights and receive feedback, fostering a deeper understanding of research methods and their applications. This assessment also reinforces academic honesty through proper citation practices and emphasizes effective communication by requiring students to clearly present their findings.

Learning Goals:

  • Research Skills: Students will locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary and secondary sources.

  • Critical Evaluation: Students will assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources, including accuracy, reliability, and relevance.

Ontario Curriculum Expectations:

  • A2.2 Locate and select information relevant to investigations from various primary and secondary sources.

  • A3.1 Assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values, and bias).

  • A3.4 Demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research.

  • A4.3 Clearly communicate the results of inquiries (e.g., write clearly, organize ideas logically, use language conventions properly) and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources.

Step 1: Topic Selection and Research Methodology

  • Choose a Topic: Select a topic related to human behavior or society (e.g., mental health, drug addiction, high school graduation rates).

  • Research: Using search engines and databases, find one resource from each of the following categories:

    • Primary Source (e.g., original documents, peer-reviewed journals, interviews, etc.)

    • Secondary Source (e.g., textbook articles, literature reviews, reports).

  • Citation: Provide proper citations in APA format for each source.

Step 2: Evaluation of Information

  • Assessment Criteria: For each resource, assess its:

    • Accuracy

    • Relevance

    • Reliability

    • Bias and inherent values

  • Reflection on Source Quality: For each source, explain its strengths and limitations in relation to your topic.

Step 3: Communication and APA Format

  • Organize and Communicate Findings: Write a clear, logically organized report, summarizing the sources you gathered and explaining their relevance to your chosen topic.

  • Academic Honesty: Ensure all sources are cited properly using APA format (both in-text and reference list).

Step 4: Discussion Forum Conversation

  • Objective: To deepen understanding through peer engagement.

  • Instructions: Post your research findings on the Brightspace Discussion Forum. Respond to at least one peer’s post. Your response should reflect an understanding of the research methods, source evaluation, and how their findings contribute to the understanding of the topic.

Discussion Prompts:

  • What challenges did you face in selecting reliable sources, and how did you address them?

  • How did the secondary source complement or challenge the findings from your primary source?

  • What strategies did you use to assess the relevance of your sources to your research question?

Overall Expectation-Based Rubric:

Criteria

Level 1 (50-59%)

Level 2 (60-69%)

Level 3 (70-79%)

Level 4 (80-100%)

Knowledge and Understanding

Limited understanding of research methods and source evaluation.

Basic understanding with minimal analysis.

Clear understanding, well-supported examples and evaluation.

Sophisticated understanding, deep connections between sources and research objectives.

Thinking and Inquiry

Weak or unclear analysis of sources; minimal critical evaluation.

Some analysis, but lacks depth or supporting details.

Thoughtful analysis with relevant examples and evaluation.

Strong critical thinking, integrating multiple perspectives and supporting arguments.

Communication

Ideas are unclear; disorganized presentation.

Basic communication; some ideas lack coherence.

Well-structured, articulate responses with clear reasoning.

Exceptionally clear, well-organized, and engaging presentation.

Application

Limited use of research findings in the assignment.

Some connections made, but lacks clear application to the research question.

Effective use of sources to support research.

Skillful integration of sources, real-world applications, and critical thinking.

2.1 Discussion Activity: Roles and Norms Homework

Course: HHS4U – Families in Canada
Type of Assessment: Live Oral Conversation (Not a Product-Based Assessment)
Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning
Method of Assessment: Conversation-Based Assessment (KTCA)

Rationale for Conversation-Based Assessment

This assessment evaluates students’ ability to articulate and analyze the influence of societal roles and norms on individuals and families. A live conversation allows students to demonstrate their understanding in real time, engage in critical discussion, and apply sociological perspectives. This format assesses communication skills, analytical thinking, and the ability to synthesize information verbally rather than through written work.

Ontario Curriculum Expectations Assessed:

  • C2.1 Explain how various roles and norms influence family structures and relationships.

  • C2.2 Analyze how gender expectations and societal norms shape individuals’ experiences in families.

  • C2.3 Assess how societal norms evolve over time and their impact on family expectations.

  • A3.1 Assess the credibility and bias of research sources.

Assignment Instructions

Step 1: Preparing for the Discussion

Before participating in the conversation, reflect on how roles and norms shape family interactions and expectations. Consider the following areas:
✅ Traditional vs. Modern Gender Roles – How have expectations for men and women evolved in families?
✅ Cultural Influences on Norms – How do different cultures define and enforce family roles?
✅ Generational Shifts in Expectations – How have norms around marriage, parenting, and career choices changed over time?
✅ Social Media & Changing Norms – How does media influence what is considered "normal" in relationships and families?

To prepare:

  • Choose a key theme (e.g., gender roles, cultural expectations, media influence).

  • Find a real-world example (e.g., a cultural tradition, a law, a social movement) that illustrates change in family norms.

  • Be ready to compare and contrast past and present perspectives.

Step 2: Participate in the Discussion Forum

In this discussion forum, you will explore and respond to the following questions regarding societal roles and norms:

  • How have societal norms shaped family roles in different cultures or time periods?
     Reflect on how societal expectations around family roles have evolved. For example, how do family roles differ across cultures or historical periods? What factors contribute to these differences?

  • What factors drive change in family expectations (e.g., law, media, economy)?
     Discuss how societal expectations related to family roles have changed over time. Consider factors such as changes in laws, economic conditions, or the influence of media in shaping family norms and expectations.

  • Are gender roles still relevant in today’s society, or are they becoming outdated?
     Reflect on the relevance of traditional gender roles in modern families. How do contemporary views on gender roles compare to past norms, and what impact does this have on family dynamics?

  • What is one tradition or expectation that should be re-examined in modern families?
     Consider one traditional or societal expectation about families that may no longer be applicable or beneficial in today’s world. Provide a reasoned argument for why this expectation should be reconsidered.

Instructions for Participation:

  • Post your initial response to these questions in 200-250 words.

  • Engage with at least two peers’ posts: Provide thoughtful feedback by identifying areas where you agree or disagree, and suggest additional insights or questions to deepen the conversation. Aim for 100-150 words per peer response.

Step 3: Reflection on the Conversation (Post-Discussion)

After the discussion, reflect on:

  • What was the most thought-provoking argument made in the discussion?

  • Did your views change after hearing different perspectives? Why or why not?

  • What key takeaway about roles and norms will you remember?

📌 Reflection Submission: You may submit a written response (1-2 paragraphs) or an audio/video reflection (1 minute).



KTCA Rubric 

Criteria

Level 1 (50-59%)

Level 2 (60-69%)

Level 3 (70-79%)

Level 4 (80-100%)

Knowledge

Demonstrates limited understanding of societal roles and norms. Ideas are unclear and lack relevance.

Demonstrates basic understanding of societal roles and norms, but ideas are somewhat incomplete or underdeveloped.

Demonstrates clear understanding of societal roles and norms, with relevant examples and concepts applied.

Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of societal roles and norms, with in-depth analysis and strong relevance to the discussion.

Thinking

Minimal analysis and critical thinking; lacks connections to different perspectives.

Some analysis and critical thinking; limited connections to other viewpoints.

Thoughtful analysis and critical thinking; provides multiple perspectives on the issues discussed.

Insightful, deep analysis and critical thinking; connects multiple perspectives, showing a well-rounded understanding of the topic.

Communication

Ideas are unclear or poorly articulated; responses lack structure and coherence.

Some ideas are communicated clearly, but some sections lack coherence or organization.

Well-structured and articulated ideas, but may lack a clear flow in some sections.

Exceptionally clear, well-organized, and engaging communication that makes complex ideas accessible and interesting.

Application

Limited application of societal norms to real-world examples or family roles.

Some application of societal norms to real-world examples, but connections are weak or underdeveloped.

Effective application of societal norms to real-world examples and family roles, with relevant connections made.

Strong, well-supported application of societal norms to real-world examples, providing significant insight into family roles and societal changes.

Lesson 3.1- Trends and Issues in Relationships (C)

Lesson 3.1 Trends and Issues in Relationships Homework

Course: HHS4U – Families in Canada
Type of Assessment: Conversation (Not a Product-Based Assessment)
Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning
Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Rationale for Conversation-Based Assessment

This assessment allows students to demonstrate their ability to discuss, analyze, and evaluate contemporary relationship trends in real time. Engaging in a live conversation helps students synthesize research, share personal insights, and engage in critical discourse about modern relationships. This format evaluates verbal communication skills, depth of understanding, and ability to engage in reflective dialogue rather than written work.

Ontario Curriculum Expectations Assessed:

  • D2.1 Explain how contemporary trends affect different types of relationships.

  • D2.2 Analyze the impact of cultural shifts, technology, and economic changes on relationship norms.

  • D2.3 Assess the role of gender, social expectations, and law in shaping relationships.

  • A3.1 Assess the credibility and bias of research sources.

Assignment Instructions

Step 1: Preparing for the Discussion

Before participating in the conversation, reflect on key trends and issues in relationships today. Consider:

✅ Changing Relationship Norms – How have dating, marriage, and family expectations evolved?
✅ Technology & Digital Relationships – What role does social media and online dating play?
✅ Impact of Gender & Social Expectations – How do traditional roles compare to modern partnerships?
✅ Economic & Legal Influences – How do financial stability and legal policies shape relationships?

To prepare:

  • Choose a key trend or issue (e.g., cohabitation, declining marriage rates, online dating, changing gender roles).

  • Find a real-world example (e.g., statistics, social trends, personal observations).

  • Be ready to discuss how this trend has changed relationships over time.



Step 2: Participating in the Brightspace Discussion Forum

You will now engage in a discussion forum on Brightspace. In this forum, you will explore:

  • How have relationships changed over time? What key trends are shaping relationships today?

  • What role does technology play in modern relationships? Is it helping or harming?

  • Are traditional gender roles in relationships still relevant, or are they evolving?

  • What major factors impact relationship choices today compared to the past? (e.g., finances, career, culture).

Your posts should:

  • Demonstrate historical awareness and real-world connections.

  • Show critical thinking about the impact of social, cultural, and technological changes on relationships.

Step 3: Reflection on the Conversation (Post-Discussion)

After the discussion, reflect on:

  • What was the most insightful or surprising point raised during the conversation?

  • Did your views on relationships change after hearing different perspectives?

  • What key takeaway about relationships today will you remember?

📌 Reflection Submission: You may submit a written response (1-2 paragraphs) or an audio/video reflection (1 minute).


























Assessment Rubric (KTCA – Conversation-Based Assessment)

Criteria

Level 1 (50-59%)

Level 2 (60-69%)

Level 3 (70-79%)

Level 4 (80-100%)

Knowledge and Understanding

Limited understanding of contemporary relationship trends.

Basic understanding, but lacks depth or real-world application.

Clear understanding with well-supported examples and research.

Sophisticated analysis, demonstrating deep connections between historical and modern relationships.

Thinking and Inquiry

Weak or unclear analysis of trends and issues in relationships.

Some analysis, but lacks depth or multiple perspectives.

Thoughtful comparisons of past and present relationship trends with relevant examples.

Strong critical thinking, integrating multiple perspectives and in-depth analysis of social trends.

Communication

Ideas are unclear and responses lack structure.

Basic communication of ideas; some responses lack coherence.

Well-structured, articulate responses with clear reasoning.

Exceptionally clear, well-organized, and engaging discussion that demonstrates strong analytical skills.

Application

Limited connection between relationship trends and societal influences.

Some connections made, but lacks real-world relevance.

Effective application of sociological perspectives to modern relationships.

Skillful integration of research, real-world applications, and sociological analysis.

Lesson 4.1 Historical Perspectives of the Family Conversation Homework

Course: HHS4U – Families in Canada
Type of Assessment: Live Oral Conversation (Not a Product-Based Assessment)
Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning
Method of Assessment: Conversation-Based Assessment (KTCA)

Rationale for Conversation-Based Assessment

This assessment method allows students to demonstrate their understanding through academic discussion rather than written work. Engaging in a live conversation helps students articulate historical perspectives on family, compare different time periods, and analyze the evolution of family structures. This format evaluates critical thinking, real-time synthesis of knowledge, and the ability to engage in reflective dialogue.

Ontario Curriculum Expectations Assessed:

  • D3.1 Analyze the impact of major social and economic changes on the historical evolution of the family.

  • D3.2 Compare different family structures in historical and contemporary contexts.

  • D3.3 Assess how historical family roles influence modern family expectations.

  • A3.1 Assess the credibility and bias of research sources.

Assignment Instructions

Step 1: Preparing for the Discussion

Before the conversation, reflect on how historical family structures have evolved over time due to changes in:

  • Economic factors (e.g., Industrial Revolution, women in the workforce).

  • Social expectations (e.g., gender roles, marriage norms, child-rearing).

  • Technology and globalization (e.g., impact on parenting, family size, and communication).

To prepare:
✅ Select a historical period (e.g., Victorian Era, 1950s, present day) to focus on.
✅ Research how family structures, roles, and expectations changed during this period.
✅ Compare past norms to modern family dynamics and be ready to discuss your findings.

Step 2: Participating in the Brightspace Discussion Forum

Instead of a live, one-on-one conversation, you will engage in a discussion on the Brightspace platform. You will:

  1. Post a response to a discussion prompt regarding historical family structures, gender roles, and the evolution of family expectations over time.

  2. Respond to at least one peer's post, comparing their views with your own research and insights.

  3. Demonstrate your ability to analyze and connect past family norms to modern family dynamics. Ensure your responses are thoughtful, well-organized, and supported by historical examples and personal insights.

You should aim to engage critically with your peers, fostering a reflective dialogue that showcases your understanding of historical and contemporary family structures.

Step 3: Reflection on the Conversation (Post-Discussion)

After the discussion, reflect on:

  • What was the most surprising thing you learned?

  • Did your perspective on historical family roles change after this discussion?

  • How can historical insights help us understand family structures today?

📌 Reflection Submission: You may submit a written response (1-2 paragraphs) or an audio/video reflection (1 minute).





























Assessment Rubric (KTCA – Conversation-Based Assessment)

Criteria

Level 1 (50-59%)

Level 2 (60-69%)

Level 3 (70-79%)

Level 4 (80-100%)

Knowledge and Understanding

Limited understanding of historical family structures and their evolution.

Basic understanding with minimal application of historical analysis.

Clear understanding with well-supported examples and historical comparisons.

Sophisticated understanding, demonstrating deep connections between historical and modern family structures.

Thinking and Inquiry

Weak or unclear historical analysis; minimal comparison to modern families.

Some analysis, but lacks depth or multiple perspectives.

Thoughtful historical comparison with relevant examples and insights.

Strong critical thinking, integrating multiple perspectives and in-depth analysis of historical shifts.

Communication

Ideas are unclear and responses lack structure.

Basic communication of ideas; some responses lack coherence.

Well-structured, articulate responses with clear reasoning and historical context.

Exceptionally clear, well-organized, and engaging discussion that demonstrates strong historical knowledge.

Application

Limited connection between historical analysis and modern family structures.

Some connections made, but lacks real-world relevance.

Effective application of historical insights to modern family expectations.

Skillful integration of historical research, modern applications, and critical perspectives.

Assessment of Learning

UNIT 1 



Type of Assessment: Unit Summative

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning

Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Learning Goal:  You will demonstrate your understanding of theoretical perspectives and research on various aspects of individual development.

Ontario Curriculum Expectations

B1

Demonstrate an understanding of theoretical perspectives and research on various aspects of individual development;

B1.1

explain individual development throughout the lifespan, according to a variety of theoretical perspectives on development (e.g., psychodynamic perspective [Sigmund Freud, Erik Erikson, Karen Horney], cognitive perspective [Lev Vygotsky], humanist perspective [Abraham Maslow, Carl Rogers], symbolic interactionist perspective [Charles Cooley, George Mead], sociocultural perspective [Urie Bronfenbrenner], evolutionary perspective [Konrad Lorenz, John Bowlby])

B1.2 

assess research on sex-based similarities and differences as well as gender-based similarities and differences (e.g., with reference to the complexity of distinguishing the effects of nature and nurture; the impact of cultural, social, and historical change on expectations associated with gender)  

B1.3

compare theories used to explain adult development in later life (e.g., Erik Erikson’s stages of generativity versus stagnation, and ego integrity versus despair; Daniel Levinson’s midlife transition; Bernice Neugarten’s concept of the social clock; George Mead’s symbolic interactionist theories)

Instructions:

  1. Sketch a design for a TWO postage stamp collection honoring TWO theoretical perspectives.

  2. By recording a video of yourself, compare how your designs represent similarities &/or differences between the theoretical perspectives you have selected.

 

Example:

On July 2, two Art Canada stamps and a souvenir sheet containing them both were issued to showcase the paintings of Prudence Heward (1896-1947). The 57¢ stamp shows Heward’s 1929 portrait of Rollande, an unconventional portrait of a young working woman from rural Quebec (Scott 2395).

This stamp depicts works of art that not only tell us about the artists, but about the men and women they portrayed and their lives and attitudes.

Designed by Helene L’Heureux, these Art Canada stamps were the first Canadian stamps printed by Lowe-Martin in seven-color offset lithography on colorless, water-activated TRC paper in 16-stamp panes.

Norms, Roles, and Institutions

Type of Assessment: Homework

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment FOR Learning

Method of Assessment: Subject association

Learning Goals:

  • Students will assess ways in which norms, values, and expectations influence individual decisions throughout the lifespan

  • Students will analyse the impact of social institutions on the socialization of individuals throughout the lifespan

HHS4U

Assessment of Learning

UNIT 3

Type of Assessment: Unit Summative

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning

Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Learning Goal:  You will demonstrate your understanding intimate relationships according to a variety of theoretical perspectives.

Ontario Curriculum Expectations

B2

The Development of Intimate Relationships: demonstrate an understanding of theoretical

perspectives and research on the development of intimate relationships;

B2.1

explain the development of intimate relationships according to a variety of theoretical perspectives (e.g., psychodynamic, evolutionary, structural functionalist, conflict theory, feminist theory, queer theory perspectives)

B2.2 

compare various theories of attraction and mate selection (e.g., evolutionary theory, filter theory, social homogamy theory, the theory of complementary needs).

B2.3

assess various theories of attraction, mate selection, and the development of intimate relationships with reference to current research that supports or contradicts them.

C2

The Effects on Intimate Relationships: demonstrate an understanding of the impact of norms,

roles, and social institutions on intimate relationships;

C2.1

analyse ways in which social norms and expectations (e.g., cultural & religious norms; expectations

of peers, friends, parents) can influence the establishment and maintenance of healthy intimate relationships.

C2.2

explain mate‐selection, courtship, and marriage customs (e.g., arranged & free‐choice marriages; use of matchmakers; civil, religious, & tribal marriage ceremonies; polygamy & monogamy) in various cultures, religions, and historical periods.

C2.3

analyse ways in which roles are negotiated in intimate relationships (e.g., with reference to division of labour, patterns of authority, decision making).

C2.4

analyse differences among roles in intimate relationships in various social, historical, and ethnocultural contexts (e.g., in traditional Islamic & Hindu societies; in First Nation or Inuit cultures; before & after the second wave women’s movement in Canada).

C2.5

analyse how social institutions (e.g., religious, economic, political institutions) can affect intimate

relations.

D2

Trends and Challenges in Intimate Relationships: demonstrate an understanding of demographic

and social trends and issues related to intimate relationships and of strategies for responding to

challenges in those relationships;

D2.1

analyse the significance of recent demographic trends relating to intimate relationships (e.g., with regard to adolescent sexual activity; cohabitation, marriage & divorce rates; same‐sex marriage; delayed age of marriage; an increase in the number of people living independently; serial monogamy; an increase in arranged marriages).

D2.2

assess the impact of current social trends, issues, and challenges on intimate relationships (e.g., with reference to electronic media, employment, healthcare, education, economic changes, the aging population, balancing work & family, an increase in the number of relationships between people of different faiths or ethnic backgrounds).

D2.3

outline strategies for avoiding and responding to various types of violence and abuse in intimate

relationships (e.g., emotional, physical, sexual, financial abuse).



Instructions:

Part 1: Mate Selection

Most marriages in Canada result from free choice mate selection, in which individuals are attracted to each other, fall in love, and decide to marry, although some marriages are still arranged. Several theories have arisen to explain mate-selection: natural selection, social homogamy, ideal mate theory, & fair exchange.

  1. Analyse the formation of your relationship using two different mate-selection theories.

  2. Describe the roles of each individual in the relationship and compare it to the norm in our society.

Part 2: Couple Relationships

Congratulations! You’re a couple. Are you an opposite-sex or same-sex couple? Are you married or common-law? Did you cohabit before you became a couple? It is customary in our society to have a ceremony to establish your relationship.

  1. Start planning locally.

  2. First things first, consider your finances. Budget for 15-20% of your combined annual gross income. Don’t forget things like a marriage application, invitations, or transportation.

  3. Present a "scrapbook" (book, website, video, etc.) of your couple ceremony. Include images to represent all aspects of the event (e.g. ring shopping, bridal shower, ceremony, reception, honeymoon, etc.).

  4. Keep in mind that scrapbooks are more meaningful when captions accompany the visuals.

Part 3: Refer to the rubric below to know how you will be graded.

instructions.text:
Functions of the family: Socialization and Theory Application

Type of Assessment: Homework

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment FOR Learning

Method of Assessment: Subject association

Learning Goals:

  • Students will describe the functions of the family, and explain the ways in which these functions are met in diverse family forms

  • Students will analyse the impact of major social and economic changes on the historical evolution of the family

  • Students will assess the impact of current social trends, issues, and challenges relating to the functioning of families

  • Students will demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research

  • Students will clearly communicate the results of their inquiries, and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources

Ontario Curriculum Expectations

B3.1

Describe the functions of the family

(e.g., reproduction, socialization of children, physical maintenance of members, nurturance and love, social control, production of goods and services), and explain the ways in which these functions are met in diverse family forms (e.g., single-parent families, two-parent families [both same-sex and heterosexual], grandparent-led families, extended families, childless families)

B3.2

Assess various theoretical perspectives on the development of family and parent-child relationships (e.g., psychodynamic, symbolic interactionist, structural functionalist, conflict theory, social exchange theory perspectives)

B3.3

Assess, with reference to current theories and research (e.g., caregiver identity theory, child and adult attachment theories, Roy Adaptation Model

of Caregiver Stress), the impact of caregiving on family relationships

C3.2

Analyse the ways in which caregiving responsibilities are carried out (e.g., with reference to the sex of caregivers; whether caregiving is paid work; the extent to which children, grandparents,

or other relatives are involved in providing care) in

diverse families (e.g., working-class and upper- middle-class families, single-parent and extended families, grandparent-led families)

Instructions:

For this assignment, select and read one of the case studies below, then answer the following questions. Use this template to organize your information.

  1. Parent-Child Theories

    1. Apply one of the parent-child theories to the people in the case study. Be sure to follow the correct format that you learned in Lesson 1.3 (key point, example, explanation) to apply theories.

 

  1. Social Science Theories

    1. Apply a second theory to explain the relationships and situation demonstrated in the case study. However, this time the theory should be one of the social science theories you examined in Unit 1, Activity 3 (Structural Functionalism, Conflict Theory, Symbolic Interactionism, Feminist).

instructions.text:
HHS4U Culminating Activity

My Family History

Your task:

For this project, you are required to research your own family. Most of us know information about our parents (where and when they were born, where they went to school, etc.), but we may not know anything further. The information can be presented in scrapbook or slide presentation format. Make sure to be creative and apply knowledge from the course.

Part 1

Family Tree

The first part of your RST requires you to do some research on your family. A family tree has you trace back your family lineage as far as you can go. This is difficult for some people so for this assignment you are only required to go back as far as your grandparents, however, if you can go back farther please do so.

  • Your tree should include a minimum of:

  • You (and siblings if you have them)

  • Your parents

  • Your grandparents

  • You can use online programs/templates, or develop your own in order to have the information presented.

**Images will help make the tree more effective**

Part 2

Generation Research

  • As we have discussed in class, the family has looked very di erent at di erent points in history.

  • Choose one of the generations on your family tree , and discuss what your family looked like at this time period (i.e. were they a ‘typical’ family? Did they break the norm? etc.).

  • Also, discuss what was going on in the world at this time and if that a ected your family at all (i.e. were your grandparents a ected by WWII? Were your parents a ected by the Cold War? Etc.) ● Why has your family evolved this way over time?

Part 3

Your Turn

● Now I want you to consider everything we have talked about in this

class and reflect on how your family has helped shape you as an individual (i.e. how have your parents helped you develop into the person you are today?

●

How has your relationship with your parents and siblings helped to shape your identity?). Make sure to include one of the theories we have discussed in class and use terms and information from the course to support your ideas.

In order for you to find all the required information, you are going to have to interview family members. You are also able to use your class notes and outside sources to round out your research.

Oral Presentation Guidelines  

Your oral report should include:

- An introduction of your topic and project.

- Presentation of each section: timeline, map, photo analysis, and reflective question.

- Conclusions and reflections on Canada's role in shaping global and national events.

RUBRIC

Student Name:
